subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I’m
going to address the topic of chaos
magick, but I have to warn you, to begin
with, that in the last 24 hours
practically, a number of things have
happened, things that are relevant to
several of the earlier “In Presence”
episodes. I’m digesting it right now.
I can't say I've fully digested
everything. But I realize that what I’m
about to share with you may sound
chaotic, which would be appropriate for a
discussion about chaos magick. But I also
have to warn you that I doubt if I can
cover this topic in sufficient depth in
the time that I normally allot for an
“In Presence”
monologue. Maybe I’ll go on longer, or
maybe this is going to take a few
installments before all the pieces of
the pie really come together. Let me
start by saying this, I have just
finished viewing a lecture on video, you
can see it on YouTube, in fact I’m going
to link to it right now, by Gary Lachman.
[deleted]
He’s an American
currently living in England, former
bass player for the punk rock band
Blondie, many of you will remember
Deborah Harry is the lead singer in that
band, as I recall. In any case, he has
written about 20 books now on
mystical, psychic, occult and esoteric
topics. He’s written about Madame
Blavatsky, Swedenborg, Rudolf
Steiner, Aleister Crowley, the people
who I also really admire and am very
interested in. He has also written a
book recently called Dark Star Rising, in
which he addresses the topic of chaos
magick. The subtitle of the book has
to do with occult influences related to
the
rise of Donald Trump and his election as
president of the United States. So, these
are all themes that are relevant to
topics I have been discussing
recently, if you’ve been following the “In
Presence” monologues I’m sure you get my
drift here. Even the discussion I had
about Philip the Ghost and the
invocation of Tulpas
is interesting.So, let me say a few
things now. I introduced the topic
of chaos magick. I can tell you this, I
don't know much about it, really. I do
know that there are several fairly well
populated groups on Facebook devoted to
chaos magick. I also know that my old
friend, Robert Anton Wilson, seems to be
highly esteemed amongst the
practitioners of chaos magick. Of
course, I’ve had lots of interactions
with Bob Wilson back in the days when I
lived in Berkeley, California, and he did
too. We were almost neighbors. Chaos
magick, as I now come to understand it,
is not so different from parapsychology. Why?
Because chaos magicians, to my
understanding, are interested in results.
They are much less interested in the
trappings that go along with magic:
the costumes, the language, the rituals.
They are only interested in the results
that can be obtained. Naturally, if
they can find ways to more effectively
achieve those results without having to
engage in all the trappings that are
found in Wicca, or the Rosicrucian
rituals, or the Golden Dawn rituals, or
the Hermetic rituals of different types,
so much the better for them.Well, I think
that's pretty close to what
parapsychologists are doing.
There may be a sense in which chaos
magicians are way ahead of
parapsychologists because, you know,
parapsychologists, as I’ve pointed out in
previous segments, have been rather
disdainful of the occult. Many of them
still are. I think that impedes the
parapsychologists from seeing what’s
really going on. But remember this,
I for the last 40 years or so have
advocated that parapsychologists pay
more attention to magic, the occult,
esoteric culture and so on. I’m not
the only one. There are other
parapsychologists who have felt this way
as long as I have. I would say
it's probably a majority viewpoint. My
best guess is that chaos magicians,
I guess they call themselves that,
and parapsychologists will probably have
a lot to talk about.
Now, Gary Lachman, in his book Dark Star
Rising, points to several factors which I
think are relevant here. One is,
you could call it meme magic. In fact,
practitioners on the alt right who do
this, do call it meme magic. You may
recall during the election, this meme of
Pepe the Frog, this big green frog
appeared widely in the media and Donald
Trump himself used that image. I’m
showing you a graphic of Donald Trump
merging with Pepe the Frog.
So, the alt right supporters who were
interested in sort of thumbing their
nose at mainstream society and approving
and supporting Donald Trump in his
campaign, well, I think they liked the
chaos he was engendering. I think they
also... let me say this, as a person who has
been a lifelong liberal Democrat and
intend to continue to be, I’ll say
this parenthetically
for those of you who are posting
comments on some of my political
remarks, two points I’d like to make. One
is, I’m well aware of the cosmic game
here. And I’m well aware that getting
caught into the world of duality is not
a final solution. So, while I
fervently identify as a liberal
Democrat, it doesn't mean that I also
don't have a larger perspective
regarding what Stanislav Groff
has called The Cosmic Game. What
seems to be black and white is often,
often, not what it seems. I know that. The
question I have to ask those of you who
criticize me, however, is do you know that?
Furthermore, let me say this, if you
think that my position is mistaken,
why don't you criticize the particular
points that I make rather than just
hurling epithets? If you do, who knows, I
might even respond. As I say, I
read all the comments, [but] it's almost
impossible for me to respond to them.
I’ve refrained from doing it generally unless
I can be specifically helpful. But now,
back to meme magick and Pepe the Frog. It
turns out, and I learned this from Gary
Lachman’s lecture, that there is another
incarnation of Pepe the Frog as the
Egyptian god of darkness and chaos, named
Kek. In effect, all of the use of the
meme of Pepe the Frog and the phrase
meme magick will put Pepe out there -
magical incantations we evoke, Pepe is a
deity who is going to help elect Donald
Trump. They were also consciously aware
that they were invoking the ancient
Egyptian god of chaos and darkness, the
frog god of Kek. There's a lot more
behind that.So, there are some people
who
believe that, in effect, they willed Donald Trump
into the presidency through these events.
Now, obviously, it's much more complex
than that because there is the politics
involved. I don’t want to get into it
any further at the movement. But, let me
say a few more things about this idea of
chaos magick. Because, you know, it was very
improbable that Trump would be elected.
It was improbable in fact that he would get
the nomination. Then it happened, for
a multiplicity of cases. Perhaps
this invocation of the ancient Egyptian
deity of darkness and chaos had
something to do with it because all of
sudden, like overnight, we were thrust
from a realm, of what I would think of as
positive, liberal Democratic growth away
from the terrible chaos of the financial
disaster of 2008 we’re on. Look at the
stock market during the Obama years, a
very positive growth curve. In any
case, now we’re in a very different era
completely. A completely different era,
psychologically. The point I was
going to make is that I think from the
perspective of many of the practitioners
of meme magick and practitioners of chaos
magick, and I suspect this is also
true for viewers of the “In Presence”
monologues and The New Thinking Allowed
interviews who are of the right wing
political persuasion,
there's something about liberal
democracy that bothers you. It seems like,
in some ways, a little too good to be
true. But, it has its own dark
side, doesn't it? Political correctness,
the sense that there's this New World
Order that's going to suppress dissent
and difference, that everybody is going
to become globalized
and integrated into a culture where we
will all be mulattoes, eventually, and lose
all of the distinct cultures that our
ancestors participated in, and other
threats as well. I’m
willing to take a good hard look at that,
of course.Besides the point, they
felt a need for change. Why else would
they invoke a deity of chaos? The
invocation of such a deity is not so
different from the invocation of the
Tibetan tulpas, or the invocation of
Philip the Ghost. I’ve had conversation
about how thought forms can become
tangible and act in the real world.
Well, Gary Lachman made a very
interesting point. He suggests that the
chaos magick people are very much in
alignment with the postmodern
philosophers who basically think there
is no ground to reality. The only ground
is that there is no ground. In other
words, it's all up for grabs, we can shape
reality according to our words, according
to our will, according to the images, the
memes that we can impose on others.
Of course, who is better equipped to
shape that reality than the president of
the United States. A man whose every word
is listened to by thousands if not
millions of people. Now, another point
Gary Lachman makes related to all of
this, for what it's worth, I don't want to
make too much of it really,
but that Donald Trump and his family
have been deeply involved with Norman
Vincent Peale and the power of positive
thinking. Once again, the idea that
your thoughts can create reality. If
you combine that with the idea that
there are no absolute truths at all, in
other words, not even absolute ethical
truths, then
imposing your thoughts on the world
is in effect the act of magick.
Who is a more powerful magician than
the president of the United States? Well,
this is all food for thought. I could
go on. There's a great deal more to it. I
can tell you, for example, that my good
friend Jason Reza Jorjani, I know who
irritates many of my fellow liberals,
Jason was deeply involved in all of this.
He was a close friend at one time with
Richard Spencer, the man who at one time made a
statement basically saying, we dreamed up
Trump and made him real. Also, Jason,
the former editor of Arktos Publishing,
they’re the publishing house that
published the books of Aleksandr Dugin.
In fact, Dugin’s books were the most
popular books published by Arktos.
Jason was at one time the
editor-in-chief of that company. Well,
Dugin is a Russian who supposedly is
close to Putin, I don't know whether
that's true or not, but there’s certainly
indications that it is true. Dugin is
viewed today as a traditionalist, a man
who wants to see the traditional Russian
values, conservative values
throughout the world. I’ve been
looking into Dugin a bit, and it turns
out at one time he was a student of
chaos magick. In fact, the emblem he uses
for his politics is the same as the
symbol for chaos magick. Here you can
see Dugin giving a lecture with that
symbol behind him. He was in fact a
student of Aleister Crowley - very, very
different from his conservative values
that he supposedly holds. So, that's
another piece of the puzzle, when you
consider the supposed Russian influence
on the Trump election. It may have been
multipronged, not just an internet attack,
but
a chaos magick attack as well. Now, I doubt very
much if Putin had anything to do with
that, but Dugin, on the other hand, is
a deep background figure for all
of this, an important Russian person
pulling strings. As I say, there’s
much, much more to this story, but I think
I’m kind of giving you an overview for
now. Its something worth pondering when
you consider that we now know
there is a long history in Nazi Germany,
in Soviet Russia, and in Democratic
America of interest in the paranormal,
the occult, the power of the mind, in
parapsychology, in New Thought, in the
power of positive thinking, in telepathic
hypnotic induction. Now, it seems even
in the invocation of ancient deities.
Of course, my friend Jason, I think, is
knowledgeable about all of these things.
Next time he visits I intend to
probe him more deeply on these topics.
But, what does this all mean for you? What
is the lesson in all of this for you? I
can only share with you at this point
what I think the lesson is for me.
That is, I am just becoming aware of
a whole realm of social activity, vibrant,
powerful, social activity relating to
parapsychology, relating to
synchronicities, relating to the occult,
that I wasn't even aware of. It started
out just yesterday, I posted the
discussion about Jacques Valle and the
world wide web and his suggestion that
the web itself could be used as a tool
for studying synchronicities. Then,
later on in the day someone posted and
said, yes, we did that experiment on
our internet radio program and got good
results. Then, I
hear from Gary Lachman and he said, “I
just gave a whole lecture going into the
topic in great depth.” And we see that
the use of the Pepe meme on the internet
was deliberately designed to induce
these synchronicities and, lo and behold,
one might say, yeah, the Trump election
was certainly a concatenation of weird and
unexplained, unusual coincidences. So, it
does suggest, to me, that the lesson is
keep my eyes wide open. There are
things going on around about me that I
didn't even suspect yesterday. Maybe
that's the same lesson for you. I urge
you to think about it. Once again,
thank you for being with me.
[credits]
